Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was reviewing the final details for my Hajj trip. It was Samir, an old acquaintance, his voice shaky as he explained his car had broken down on a deserted road. He needed help, and quickly—no one else was picking up. I glanced at the envelope on my desk, the one with my Hajj savings, the one I’d guarded for years. Samir hinted he might need a loan to cover repairs and a tow, promising to pay me back soon. As a Muslim, I’d been dreaming of this pilgrimage, and my friends were all set to go this year. But as an acquaintance, I knew the right thing was to help when someone reached out in need. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: the sacred duty I’d waited for, and the immediate call for support from someone who trusted me. I stared at my phone, torn, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
